title: 109_s2636
content: The "Oil Company Accountability Act" may be cited as the short title. It introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The section outlines a general rule where individuals are treated as having made a $500 payment towards taxes for the year 2006. The Secretary is required to remit this payment to taxpayers within 30 days of enactment. Certain individuals, estates, trusts, and nonresident aliens are not eligible for this payment. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the United States Code, and a clerical amendment is included. The Oil Company Accountability Act amends Section 1324(b)(2) of title 31, United States Code. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Oil Company Accountability Act includes a provision for the revaluation of LIFO inventories of large integrated oil companies. The amendments made by this section, including an energy tax rebate, will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. The Oil Company Accountability Act mandates integrated oil companies to adjust the value of historic LIFO inventories by a set amount and reduce the cost of goods sold accordingly. If the adjustments exceed the cost of goods sold, the gross income will increase by the excess amount. The "layer adjustment amount" is calculated based on $18.75 multiplied by the number of barrels of crude oil. The term "layer adjustment amount" refers to the product of $18.75 multiplied by the number of barrels of crude oil represented by a historic LIFO layer. This adjustment does not constitute a change in accounting method and does not result in additions to tax for underpayments of estimated tax. For applicable integrated oil companies, underpayments of estimated tax related to installment payments for a taxable year can be adjusted under section 6655 of the Internal Revenue Code. The term "applicable integrated oil company" is defined based on production and gross receipts criteria. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES FOR LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. A dual capacity taxpayer is defined as a person subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession of the United States, who receives a specific economic benefit. Any amount paid by such taxpayers to a foreign country or possession will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has special rules for dual capacity taxpayers who receive economic benefits from foreign countries or possessions.
